entry.title: Over Half of Replace-by-Fee-Rate Replacements Are Mined
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the concept of pure replacement by fee rate and specifically addresses concerns related to the 2x coefficient proposed for transaction fees in a blockchain network. The sender expresses an understanding and initial support for the idea of using a fee rate mechanism to manage transactions but raises concerns about the practical implications of applying a 2x multiplier to these rates. The concern is primarily focused on the potential for users to overpay significantly due to this coefficient, questioning its necessity for the system's functionality.
The conversation delves into the technical strategy behind employing a 2x coefficient, suggesting it might be intended as a safeguard against denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, where attackers could exploit lower thresholds to continuously increment fee rates by minimal amounts, thereby congesting the network. However, the sender proposes a reconsideration of the coefficient's magnitude, suggesting that a lower threshold, such as 1.1x, could effectively serve the same preventive purpose against DoS attacks while imposing a less severe financial burden on users. This suggestion is based on the argument that a smaller increase (e.g., from 100 satoshis/byte to 110 satoshis/byte) would be more manageable and fairer to users than doubling the fee rate (100 to 200 satoshis/byte), especially when considering scenarios where the next block's fee rate might only slightly exceed the original (e.g., 105 satoshis/byte).
